bibl.title: Letter from Jefferson Randolph Kean to Mrs. Mason Young, May 19, 1901

div1.p: Kean discusses life at Camp Lazear; including acquaintances and political trouble involving his new quarters.

div1.head: Letter from Jefferson Randolph Kean to Mrs. Mason Young, May 19, 1901

opener.dateline:
Columbia Bks
HEADQUARTERS DEPARTMENT
OF HAVANA AND PINAR DEL RIO,
QUEMADOS, CUBA.
May 19 (1901)

div1.p:
When the Sedgwick
came in without that pre-
cious box of dry goods for
Louise she nearly threw
a fit and her state of
mind was not improved
by the pessimistic tone of
your letter which came
yesterday. But this en-
dorsement of Capt. Palmer
gives her again a ray of
hope, & I hasten to send
it to you in order that if
you have not received it
you may inquire for a package
addressed to Mrs Mason
as he stated that it was re-
turned to that address-

We have had two letters
from Mama since her
arrival in Lynchburg
and she seems to have
finished her journey
very successfully and got
across the City to New
Jersey all right in spite
of the slip-up about Mason's
meeting her- How she
did so, she failed to say
with that curious epistolary
unsatisfactoriness which is
a characteristic of the Prescott
blood, & of which my father
used constantly to complain.
I hope Mason did not worry himself
about the matter, which could not have
been helped & turned out all right. I
feel much obliged to him for his willing-
ness in the matter. We had Hattie Bar-
ling & her husband Dr Trotten out to dinner
last night and the Burton girls and a
couple of young Cavalrymen Mr Wessen & Mr
Long to meet them. Hattie looks quite
pretty but is as slim as a reed- They are
keeping house on Tacon St. about fifty yards
from the palace & the same distance from
Gen Ludlow's old Hdqrs- which by the way the
Dunns now occupy- Well Gran Gen Woods
determination to build me a house at Colum-
bia Bks seems to have filled Col. Bald-
win with a jealous rage, and he has been
as nasty as possible about it. The latest
development was his designation of the lower
end of the garrison for its location just be-
cause I wanted the upper end. I told him
that Gen. Wood had mentioned the upper
end as his preference, to which he replied
that that would not change him but rather
the reverse. So I reported the matter to Gen-
Wood's aide McCoy saying that I did not
HEADQUARTERS DEPARTMENT
OF HAVANA AND PINAR DEL RIO,
QUEMADOS, CUBA.
particularly case, but de-
sired General Wood to
know the decision, in case
the General did care.
I then took occasion to
mention to Col. B. what
I had told McCoy.

So yesterday out came a
message from the General
to put it at the upper
end and Col. B. is
enraged accordingly.

It is a pretty hard slap
in the face for a Colonel
to get, but he invites it by
never acting with justice
or good faith or kindly
& obliging motives.

The beautiful Bobs dis-
tinguished himself last
week by cutting two teeth
in three days, one upper
& one lower. He is getting
to be very smart and
cunning. Yesterday when
we started out in the car-
riage and did not take
him he was much insulted
and threw his arms about
Emma's neck & sobbed, &
would not look at us
at all when we called
him. Emma who is per-
fectly devoted to him is
always delighted when he
turns to her for comfort
Please tell Mr Young that we greatly
enjoyed his letter and I hope soon to
answer it. Louise & Martha have gone
to Sunday school.
Goodbye dear Gran with much love
